channel.title: The presedential facts
channel.description:
[b]First off, Go to google, go anywhere. I wrote this myself. If you say I didn't, provide a link. I DARE YOU.[/b]
Barack Obama. So it's not much of a secret who I was voting for in the 2008 presidential election. Now yes, I am a registered democrat and I tend to attach more to what the democrats
have stated then republicans. But that's MY opinion. The point of this, is to tell WHY I've voted for Barack Obama.
Now, I'm not saying that I agree 100% with Barack Obama. In fact, I tend to
only agree with around 70% of his plans. but would this still keep me from voting for
him? No. I would vote not on the plans, but I admire him, for his integrity to stnad up
for what he thinks is wrong even when It's un popular to do that.
While a candidates issues on, immagration, taxation, economics, ect, certainly
do matter, what matters more to me especially when were dealing with an Executive
position liek the presedency, is our personal qualities. I'm not talking about things
like a life story, memories, yet i'm talking about things like temperment, manegerial
skills, and intelectual curiosity.
Just think of this. Here in texas, there may be a number of voters, who vote
for there candidate souly on one issue, such as abortion. well yes, the president does
play a PART in the abortion issue, one presidents point of justices are not enough to
change the whole abortion issues. This applies however to many issues the cheif
executive does play a part at the small issue at hand, but the fate of any given issue
does not rest in the fate of the president, NEARLY as much, as most people think.
My basic point I'm trying to make is even if you disagree with Obama on some
issues, when voting for president in my opinion, there are much more important things
to consider. The last 8 years have not at all been great for america under the
leadership of george bush, and yes, it's done enourmous damage to how we're viewed by
the rest of the world...
But the most important issue TO ME, is who can BEST restore our national
standing, in the eyes, of the international communities. We are the most powerful
nation in the world, that is a fact, but in order for that power to mean anything, we
MUST maintain the respect, in the eyes of the rest of the world. So which candidate
will best repair our standing in the eyes of the international community? I don't think
there's much choice.. Barack Obama.
Lets think. John McCain wants to continue most of George Bush' policies, as do
most republicans. Now you can think whatever you want about that, but the fact of the
matter is the continuation of george bush' polocies DEFINATELY ARE NOT, a popular
standpoint, from anyone in these united states. If we were to elect John McCain
president, the world would therefor see this election, as a failed attempt of the
united states, to provide and end, to the George W. Bush era. In return, our
internationally inpopularity would become a very difficult imposition towards Senator
McCain.
Obama, on the oher hand, Is wildly popular internationally and in the eyes of
the international community, Barack IS SEEN as americas great chance to redeem itself
from these last 8 years. Restored favoribility in the eyes of the international
community would ONCE AGAIN allow america, to use its power, to the fullest.
My opinion as well as 70+% of americans, is that Barack Obama would be a much
more successful cheif diplomat, than McCain.
Keep in mind that is ONLY the international side of things. If I wanted to I
could go through Domestic governments. This is our time. This is the time for america, This is the time for you, the time for me, and the time
for laby liberty, to return its standpoint, AS THE MOST POWERFUL NATION EVER! -Tony Bunker. ©RubSca INC.

item.title: The presedential facts
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Yz85Racer:

NO ONE FUCKING CARES ABOUT THE AMERICAN PRESIDENTIAL DEBATE EXCEPT AMERICA. Seriously, stop making so many fucking topics about it, there’s more than America on the globe, however the American’s don’t think so.

FUCKING BOLD THIS. YOU STUPID FUCKING AMERICUNTS.

Read full topic

item.title: The presedential facts
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

WOW YEA I ADMIRE HIM SO LETS VOTE ON HIM!

That’s the kind of attitude that makes the US such a shitty country. All you fags care about is the image of the president. What you don’t understand is, that the US is actually quite close to a dictatorship. Actually, it’s a dictatorship with freedom of speech (as far as its possible). You can only choose from two parties: Democrats and Republicans. In a democratic country all party’s get an equal amount of media attention, but is that true in the US? NO! And secondly, in a democratic country representatives of the population rule the country. See that word: representatives. Yes, its a plural. Not one president.

And the bullshit called ‘Electoral college’ doesn’t work either. What if one candidate has one less vote in every state? He gets no votes at all? Keep in mind that ‘the winner takes all’.

Read full topic

item.title: The presedential facts
item.dc:creator: @tonypker13 tonypker13
item.description:
@tonypker13 wrote:

[quote=“chrisn2323, post:10, topic:241482”][quote author=tonypker13 link=topic=317828.msg2521198#msg2521198 date=1225864604]

Wow, you registered as a Democrat at the age of 14? Way to go on stealing that.

Registered meaning active with the community of democrats, I won’t be legally registered till 18.

You weren’t legally registered as a democrat, but you legally voted at the age of 14. I get it.

If you don’t understand the concept from a 14 year old, you’re an idiot. No I didn’t LEGALLY VOTE, But I supported him and I stated my reason to why I WOULD HAVE voted for him

why would you have voted for him?

I stated an entire document on that…
[/quote]
where?[/quote]
My whole topic…

Read full topic
